description:
From Middle English *wadlen, frequentative form of waden, equivalent to wade +‎ -le. Compare Old High German wadalōn (“to roam; wander”), Middle High German wadelen, wedelen (“to wander; rove”), German wedeln (“to waggle”).
First known use in English in a version of the Song of Roland around the year 1400. (Source:OED online)

verbs.description: waddle (third-person singular simple present waddles, present participle waddling, simple past and past participle waddled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To walk with short steps, tilting the body from side to side.
